claim: Months are based on the solar cycle.

supporting.text: Months are primarily based on the lunar cycle, with most traditional calendars using the approximate 29.5-day period of the Moon's phases.

attacks.text: Months are primarily based on the lunar cycle, with most traditional calendars using the approximate 29.5-day period of the Moon's phases.
Modern Gregorian months are based on the solar cycle, with fixed lengths unrelated to lunar phases.
Even in the Gregorian calendar, the concept of months originates from lunar cycles, though their lengths were later standardized for solar alignment.
Many cultures historically used purely lunar calendars (e.g., Islamic), proving months can exist independently of solar cycles.
Solar-based months became dominant because they better align with agricultural seasons and yearly cycles.

supporting.text: The Gregorian calendar, the most widely used calendar today, has months of arbitrary lengths (28–31 days) that do not align with the solar cycle.

attacks.text: The Gregorian calendar, the most widely used calendar today, has months of arbitrary lengths (28–31 days) that do not align with the solar cycle.
The Gregorian calendar's months are derived from historical lunar calendars, which were later adjusted to fit the solar year, showing a partial connection to solar cycles.

Many cultures historically used purely lunar calendars (e.g., Islamic calendar), proving months don’t inherently require solar alignment.

supporting.text: The solar cycle is reflected in the year's length (365.24 days), not in the division of months, which are cultural or historical constructs.

attacks.text: The solar cycle is reflected in the year's length (365.24 days), not in the division of months, which are cultural or historical constructs.
Many ancient calendars, such as the Roman calendar, originally had months based on lunar cycles, which are indirectly influenced by the solar cycle.

The Gregorian calendar, the most widely used today, adjusts months to fit the solar year, showing a modern solar-based influence on month divisions.

supporting.text: Ancient solar-based calendars, like the Egyptian civil calendar, had months that were fixed at 30 days, unrelated to the solar year's division.

attacks.text: Ancient solar-based calendars, like the Egyptian civil calendar, had months that were fixed at 30 days, unrelated to the solar year's division.

The 5-day epagomenal period was still a fixed addition and did not dynamically adjust the months to the solar cycle.
